physical_examinations.vital_signs: Serum potassium level varied between 2.3 to 4.4 mEq/L
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: Neurologic examination revealed the patient to be well-built and strong, with no evidence of muscular atrophy; however, muscle power was less than expected. On occasions, the patient was unable to stand upon waking.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Initially, the patient experienced muscle weakness that disappeared within several hours. Furthermore, during periods of hypokalemia (potassium levels 2.3 mEq/L), he experienced pronounced weakness; when serum potassium levels increased, grip and eyelid myotonia became apparent without weakness.

physical_examinations.vital_signs: Serum potassium levels ranged from 3.4 to 4.0 mEq/L
physical_examinations.relevant_findings: ECG showed decreased T wave amplitude and appearance of U wave during low potassium episodes.
physical_examinations.changes_over_time: Grasping power decreased in cold temperature (2.5 °C) and improved in warmer conditions (37 °C), correlating with myotonia becoming more prominent as temperature increased.
